content:
This relatively simple PR got stuck over a question of whether it's fine to have two versions of a lemma, one stating ¬ A → B, and the other stating ¬ B → A. Is there any sort of general guidance for these situations?
#20502
I'm sure we have any number of those in the library already
This PR is awaiting-author because you haven't added the other version yet.
It is not blocked from my point of view
Well, it's more like, I'd rather not add the other version, and I wanted a second opinion
In this particular case, adding these other versions would mean having 8 total theorems instead of 4
And as I argue I do think one version is quite more useful than the other

Worth pointing out that in successor orders without maximum elements (like the cardinals, where this theorem is currently used in!), ¬ IsSuccPrelimit is just the same as being a successor. So said theorem should probably be restated.

More generally (this also applies to some of @Martin Dvořák's PRs), you are free to disregard reviewer feedback, but you should then expect everything to take longer. There are now always > 200 PRs in the queue and not much time is available to debate basic issues that were already settled by precedent PRs. I would much rather focus our efforts on new mathematics or known pain points.
note that prs with awaiting-author or merge-conflict aren't on the queue, so they likely won't get reviewed
Yeah, this isn't urgent by any means. I just wanted to make sure we were getting a particular design aspect right.
If the general consensus is that we don't mind having 4 extra theorems that are almost the same as 4 other theorems then I'll just add them so we can all move on
I think we're generally not strongly against, in any case, and if your reviewer asks to add such corollaries, adding them is likely to be the easiest way forward
Alright, I'll add them in a bit.
I added the contrapositives back as suggested. The PR has just been sitting there for the past month.
